name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS @SenatorLeahy Thank you to @Tim_Cook for joining me at @SiliconSlopes Summit 2021.

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS @SenatorLeahy Tim Cook: Listening to the reaction here, it might be the best decision I‚Äôll ever make.

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS @SenatorLeahy Mike Lee: There‚Äôs something amazing we‚Äôve developed here, over generations, it‚Äôs called fry sauce. I highly recommend it. Would you consider serving it in your dining areas?

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS @SenatorLeahy Mike Lee: I can‚Äôt live without my iPad. I take it with me everywhere, hearings, meetings. The only way I can read everything I vote on without carrying a truckload of paper, is on my iPad.

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS @SenatorLeahy Tim Cook to Mike Lee: Other than your phone, what would you say is the one piece of technology you can‚Äôt live without?

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS @SenatorLeahy Tim Cook: A privacy ‚Äúback door‚Äù would be terrible for our consumers. You can‚Äôt make a ‚Äúback door‚Äù for only the good guys. If there‚Äôs a door, anyone can find a way in.

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS @SenatorLeahy Tim Cook: I don‚Äôt have the ability to come into your house uninvited. I shouldn‚Äôt have the ability to get into your data.

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS @SenatorLeahy Tim Cook: We feel a significant responsibility for our customers to make sure they are taken care of with privacy. That‚Äôs why we believe in encryption. We don‚Äôt have the tools to unlock your phone. The only person with a key to your phone is you.

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS @SenatorLeahy Mike Lee to Tim Cook: Why is this such a priority for Apple and what do you make of the state of privacy protections today? What role does encryption play in efforts to protect user privacy?

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS Mike Lee: We fought a revolution in part because of excessive intrusion into our privacy. Today, our personal details aren‚Äôt just in papers. They‚Äôre all over in our data. That‚Äôs why I worked with @SenatorLeahy to pass the USA Freedom Act which ended mass phone record collection.

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS Tim Cook to Mike Lee: What‚Äôs your view on the dangers of unchecked data collection?

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS Mike Lee: There‚Äôs always something you can find that interests you. A few weeks ago on a whim, I wanted to learn Morse code, it turns out there‚Äôs an app for that. We live in a time and age when you can do what interests you. If you want to learn or do something, you can.

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS Tim Cook to Mike Lee: I‚Äôm so impressed by young people today ‚Äî by their values, their ambition, their sense of purpose. What advice do you have for young people today looking to find their life‚Äôs work?

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS Tim Cook: All too often technology gets lumped together with big tech. It‚Äôs easy to lump things together, but it‚Äôs rarely correct to do so. Just like you don‚Äôt want to lump people together, you don‚Äôt want to lump businesses together.

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS Tim Cook: Robust tech competition is important. For any functioning market to continue innovating, you need competition. Our competitors make us a better company.

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS Mike Lee to Tim Cook: From your perspective, what‚Äôs the value of competition, and how can we make the technology space more competitive?

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS Mike Lee: My Government Spectrum Valuation Act would help us give more broadband access to more people.

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS Mike Lee: Permitting for broadband infrastructure can gum up the process. My UNSHACKLE Act would help that permitting get done faster to build out the necessary skeleton of our broadband system.

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS Mike Lee: Innovation requires access to broadband. It needs to be able to work its magic everywhere. Rural, urban, and everywhere in between.

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS Mike Lee: Utah has been an early pioneer in becoming a regulatory sandbox. Innovators can see where we are going better than regulators. New ideas are all too often restricted by burdensome regulatory environments. Utah is leading the way in giving new ideas regulatory freedom.

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS Mike Lee: The youth of our state are one of our biggest advantages. We have a young population, a lot of people moving in, and a lot of people getting involved in tech to do good in the world.

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Ancestry @CanvasLMS Tim Cook: Four-year college is one path, but it‚Äôs only one. There are so many jobs that don‚Äôt require four-year degrees.

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes Tim Cook : @Ancestry, @CanvasLMS , and many other Utah tech companies represent what tech is about -- helping humanity move forward.

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes @Tim_Cook : ‚ÄúUtah truly deserves the name @SiliconSlopes.‚Äù

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes Mike Lee: ‚ÄúI always enjoy getting to introduce a friend to another group of friends. Nothing says entrepreneurship like @SiliconSlopes or @Tim_Cook. So I‚Äôm glad I could help bring these groups together.‚Äù

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: @tim_cook @siliconslopes Josh James: ‚ÄúWhen it comes to technology, Senator Lee has worked to protect innovation, American ingenuity and competition that our entrepreneurs value.‚Äù

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: I look forward to improving antitrust enforcement this Congress. It is imperative that we ensure markets work for consumers, not just monopolists. It is equally imperative that we not cede this task to the radical left. The consumer welfare standard is essential to both. 5/5

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: We need the enforcers to (finally) enforce the antitrust laws against those who harm competition and consumers, including Big Tech. But we need to do it in a way that doesn't allow judges to usurp Congress's legislative role. 4/5

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: Let's also note what the consumer welfare standard is NOT: it is not a narrow concern with price. As Judge Bork wrote, it encompasses ‚Äúinnovation, choice among differing products" and quality. That more than covers the ways in which markets like Big Tech are failing us. 3/5

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: What is the consumer welfare standard? It's a guardrail that ensures 1) the primary beneficiaries of the antitrust laws are the people, not big business; and 2) that unelected judges are not allowed to use antitrust to advance their own political preferences. 2/5

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: There‚Äôs a lot of talk about antitrust legislation this Congress. One thing lost in many proposed reforms: the consumer welfare standard is not a get-out-of-jail-free card for Big Tech. We don‚Äôt need to change the law, we need to enforce it. 1/5

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: If you‚Äôre on social media today and agree please get the word out on this and contact your Senators. It‚Äôs not too late. The bill isn‚Äôt finished. A big, bipartisan coalition can still win this. We can #GoBig4Charity. Who‚Äôs with me? (15/15)

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: This is not a partisan or ideological issue. It‚Äôs more like a blind spot we want everyone to see. Congress is understandably focused on business liquidity. We‚Äôre digging deep to rescue the economy. We have to do the same for our equally important civil society. (14/15)

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: That‚Äôs why a one-year, charitable deduction is essential to a comprehensive coronavirus relief package. Rs and Ds are ready to #GoBig4Charity. We just need the chance to show it. The base bill can still be changed, or we try to offer a bipartisan amendment on the floor. (13/15)

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: This morning, millions are attending virtual church services in their living rooms, praying that this crisis passes. And it will. And when it does, we‚Äôre going to need those churches, and all our service orgs, back on the front lines to rebuild and renew our communities. (12/15)

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: And based on conversations I‚Äôve had the last few days with Republican and Democrat colleagues, I am morally certain that there is overwhelming bipartisan support for a huge-but-temporary, one-year policy fix for the charitable giving deduction. (11/15)

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: This year, we‚Äôre going to *want* all Americans ‚Äì especially rich ones! ‚Äì pouring their money into local charities. If there must be a cap, $300,000 or $30,000 makes *much* more sense than $300. (10/15)

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: The American people are ready to ‚Äúgo big‚Äù with their own personal contributions to the national relief effort. But Congress has to help them do it. In all honesty, for this one year, the deduction shouldn‚Äôt be capped at all. (9/15)

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: Non-profits are looking at shortfalls this year in the tens, maybe hundreds of billions of dollars. Ten percent of U.S. jobs are in the non-profit sector. These organizations don‚Äôt need a bailout ‚Äì they need blow-out. Just this one time, this one year. (8/15)

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: This is crucial. Fixing the charitable deduction for 2020 may give our relief efforts the best policy bang for the buck. Unfortunately, the draft proposal would cap this special, one-time deduction at‚Ä¶ $300 per person! That‚Äôs short by at least one zero. (7/15)

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: The good news is, negotiators of Phase 3 are aware of this need. The first draft includes a 1 time, 1 year fix that moves the charitable deduction ‚Äúabove the line‚Äù on 2020 tax forms. That would enable all tax filers to deduct charitable donations from their taxable income. (6/15)

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: Ivy League universities and the Smithsonian Institution may be fine. But small and medium-sized local non-profits ‚Äì the lifeblood of American culture, cooperation, and community ‚Äì are going to be hanging by a thread. Congress has to make them a priority. (5/15)

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: Think about what months of social distancing and shrunken family budgets will do to churches, charities, soup kitchens, homeless shelters, drug rehab centers, museums, elderly outreach, libraries, youth sports leagues, orchestras and theater companies? (4/15)

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: It‚Äôs not just the for-profit economy that is suffering and will suffer from the COVID outbreak. Civil society ‚Äì all those millions of non-profits around the country ‚Äì are getting hammered too. (3/15)

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: In D.C., the theme of the relief effort is to ‚Äúgo big.‚Äù Members on both sides want to overwhelm the fears and uncertainty now strangling our economy. But in this crisis, it‚Äôs not enough just for the *government* to ‚Äúgo big‚Äù ‚Äì we have to empower *everyone* to go big, too. (2/15)

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: Nothing in the First Step Act gives inmates early release. It only incentivizes participation in recidivism reduction programs. At all times the Bureau of Prisons retains all authority over who does and does not qualify for early release. 5/

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: What the First Step Act does do is encourage rehabilitation by incentivizing inmates to participate in recidivism reduction programs by giving them time credits that can help them qualify for prerelease custody. 4/

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: Second, and more importantly, the First Step Act does not ‚Äúgive early release‚Äù to anyone. Anyone claiming it does, does not understand how the bill works. 3/

name: Mike Lee

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: Here‚Äôs a quick update on today‚Äôs #SCOTUS hearing so far: https://t.co/8rEnaUFsyr

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: There‚Äôs a better way for the #Senate to approach its work. This process should be about a jurist‚Äôs qualifications, character, and approach to judging. It should not be about results in a select number of cases.

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: This undermines the legitimacy of the courts. Over time, no free people would accept a judiciary that simply imposes its own preferences on the country, absent fidelity to legal principle.

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: Every current member of the Supreme Court has adhered to a similar principle.

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: Sure enough, last term in Ortiz v. United States, #SCOTUS considered a case implicating the scope of Marbury. Likewise, Justice Ginsburg created the so-called ‚ÄúGinsburg standard‚Äù‚Äîno previews, forecasts, or hints.

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: Nominees, for the most part, have resisted trading confirmation in exchange for promises on how they‚Äôll vote. To give two famous examples: Justice Scalia refused to say whether Marbury v. Madison was settled law, on the ground that it could come before him.

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: This history shows that, over the better part of a century, the Judiciary Committee has gradually created a norm in which members demand that nominees talk about specific cases in return for favorable treatment.

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: Without getting into the gory details, suffice to say that Senator Ted Kennedy and Judge Bork did not agree on constitutional law. Kennedy‚Äôs response was to savage ‚Äì unfairly ‚Äì the results he thought Bork would reach.

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: Twenty-eight years later, the Senate considered Robert Bork‚Äôs nomination. This was another turning point, and in my view, remains a rock-bottom moment for the Senate.

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: Justice Stewart‚Äôs 1959 nomination was another turning point. Senators seeking to resist Brown v. Board of Education wanted to grill Stewart about his views on integration. Others wanted to grill Stewart about his views on national security.

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: But Senators also worried that Frankfurter was a radical based on his defense of anarchists in court. So again, Senators wanted assurances Frankfurter would reach certain results. Frankfurter, however, declined to engage w/Senators & insisted his public record spoke for itself

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: The next important moment was in 1939, when Justice Frankfurter became the first #SCOTUS nominee to testify before the Senate. At the time, Frankfurter was controversial in part because he was he was born overseas.

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: They didn‚Äôt ask Brandeis to testify, but asked outside witnesses to talk about his nomination.

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: But Senators also wanted to determine whether Brandeis would use a seat on #SCOTUS to advocate for progressive causes he championed as a public-interest attorney. They wanted to know how he would vote in particular cases.

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: The first #SCOTUS confirmation hearing occurred in 1916, when Justice Brandeis was nominated. Brandeis was controversial for several reasons‚Äîincluding, it has to be said, because he was Jewish.

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: When you look at the history, that is precisely why confirmation hearings developed‚Äîso that Senators could ask nominees how they would vote in particular cases.

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: Some of these unfair questions will ask him to promise to vote a certain way in particular cases likely to come before the Court.

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: Over the next few days, senators will ask Judge #Kavanaugh questions about #SCOTUS cases, his record, and his qualifications. Some of these questions will be fair. Many others will be unfair.

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: Let‚Äôs insist on a reassertion of the American people‚Äôs control over their government and of their land. #utpol #SIPublicLands

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: When ordinary Americans control their communities and land, it is good for both. When the federal government wields exclusive control, it is good for neither. #utpol #SIPublicLands

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: We have the opportunity to honor the promise the federal government made to Utah and Western states when they joined the Union. #utpol #SIPublicLands

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: Small reforms here and there are important. But we have to start pushing for what we actually want. We must fight to return these lands. #utpol #SIPublicLands

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: Finally, our long-term goal must be the transfer of federal lands to the states. And that is the aim of the third bill that I intend to introduce. #utpol #SIPublicLands

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: This ‚Äúnew‚Äù Homestead Act would allow states, local governments, and individuals to petition the government to use federal land for affordable housing‚Ä¶ or education‚Ä¶ or health care. #utpol #SIPublicLands

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: The second bill I plan to introduce is a new Homestead Act ‚Äì one to help ordinary Americans in the 21st century. #utpol #SIPublicLands

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: Specifically, my bill would prohibit the president from designating or expanding a national monument in the state unless both Congress and the state legislature pass resolutions approving the designation. #utpol #SIPublicLands

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: The first, the Protecting Utah‚Äôs Rural Communities Act, would protect Utah from future Antiquities Act abuses by giving Utah the same protections currently enjoyed by Wyoming and Alaska. #utpol #SIPublicLands

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: Our immediate task is to rein in that government and reclaim a space for ordinary Americans to live in freedom. I am working on three specific bills to do just that. #utpol #SIPublicLands

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: Rural Americans want what all Americans want: a dignified, decent-paying job. A family to love and support. A healthy community whose future is determined by local residents‚Äînot by their self-styled betters thousands of miles away. #utpol #SIPublicLands

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: Locals aren‚Äôt as lucky. While tourism has contributed much to the West, communities can‚Äôt survive on it alone. It is a complement to ‚Äì not a substitute ‚Äì for broader economic development. #utpol #SIPublicLands

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: They delight in seeing vast swathes of untouched lands, fulfilling their idyllic notions of the West where they can jet in, spend a few days at the cabin, take pictures of animals, and then retreat to their enclaves on the coasts. #utpol #SIPublicLands

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: Things have only gotten worse since. An even more extreme environmental movement, an alliance of privilege between celebrities, activists, and corporate elites now want to save the Earth at the expense of our rural communities. #utpol #SIPublicLands

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: No longer would it be the official policy of the United States government to sell back the land and entrust it to the people. Instead, the policy would be to keep the land for itself.  #utpol #SIPublicLands

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: And in 1976, Congress formalized federal control over federal lands by passing the Federal Land Policy and Management Act. This repealed the Homestead Acts and completely upended federal government‚Äôs public land policy. #utpol #SIPublicLands

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: The amount of grazing on federal land went into steep decline, causing an exodus from the range that was never reversed. #utpol #SIPublicLands

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: Between the mid-1960s and 1980, the amount of wilderness rose from 11.5 million acres to 82.7 million acres‚Äîan increase of 716% in less than two decades. #utpol #SIPublicLands

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: The activists used land-use restrictions as an ‚Äúall-purpose tool for stopping economic activity,‚Äù in the words of political scientist R. McGreggor Cawley. #utpol #SIPublicLands

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: But in the 60s and 70s environmental activists began exploiting public fears about overpopulation and pollution. #utpol #SIPublicLands

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: The first westerners were optimistic about federal control of western lands. Teddy Roosevelt and Gifford Pinchot advocated for active management of the land, in cooperation with local interests. #utpol #SIPublicLands

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: Fifty, sixty, even seventy percent of the land within Western states‚Äô boundaries was ‚Äì and remains ‚Äì controlled by Washington. #utpol #SIPublicLands

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: While they were ultimately successful in petitioning Congress to transfer their public lands from federal to state management, Western states have not been so lucky. #utpol #SIPublicLands

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: Take Illinois and Missouri, for example. At one point, the federal government controlled more than 90% of their land. #utpol #SIPublicLands

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: The promise to sell federal lands in Utah is right there, enshrined in federal law. But, unlike states farther East, the commitment to us was never honored. #utpol #SIPublicLands

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: When Utah came into the Union in 1896, Section 9 of its statehood enabling legislation declared that public land located within the state ‚Äúshall be sold by the United States subsequent to the admission of said state into the union.‚Äù #utpol #SIPublicLands

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: While Easterners and Midwesterners had almost-total control of the land within their boundaries, Western states like Utah entered the Union on inferior terms ‚Äì as tenants to negligent landlords. #utpol #SIPublicLands

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: But by the time Utah and other states entered the Union, Congress had turned its attention elsewhere. Manifest destiny left us behind. #utpol #SIPublicLands

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: The Homestead Acts were an engine for middle-class opportunity and growth and set the American standard for the disposition of public resources. #utpol #SIPublicLands

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: The cornerstone of this policy was the Homestead Acts which transferred 270 million acres of land out of federal control and into the hands of ordinary Americans. #utpol #SIPublicLands

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: Throughout the 19th century, Lawmakers sought to facilitate expansion of the nation by acquiring land‚Äîand then transferring it to the people, so they could live out their lives as responsible citizens of the republic. #utpol #SIPublicLands

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: How did it come to pass that nearly half of the land in the West is owned by the federal government, compared to just 5 percent of the land in the East? #utpol #SIPublicLands

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: The power to declare war belongs to Congress. By tabling this measure today, we have chosen yet again to abdicate our constitutional responsibility.

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: If we choose in this moment to table this resolution we are making a choice to be willfully blind to the exercise of a power that belongs to us. https://t.co/oo3zZbJg9i

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: This is a fast track process, this is really why the war power resolution matters here. It helps the Senate exercise it‚Äôs Article I Section 8 war power. 6/6

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: The war powers resolution provides us with the internal procedural mechanism for putting this up for a vote. This is a privileged motion, meaning we can get it brought to the floor and doesn‚Äôt require what we call cloture. 5/6

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: That doesn‚Äôt mean it (the War Power Resolution) is unconstitutional. It‚Äôs not. This is exactly what the Constitution contemplates. 4/6

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: Now, that‚Äôs not surprising because the whole purpose of the War Powers Resolution was to allow Congress to exercise its power to declare war, so presidents are naturally going to resist efforts to restrict and restrain their power. 3/6

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: Senate doesn't need to eliminate filibuster. Better solution is to work more than 3 days per week. Allow time for debate and deliberation.

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: The real problem in the Senate isn't the filibuster. What we really need is for Senate to be the Senate: an open, deliberative body.

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: What a healthy Senate lacks in efficiency, it makes up for with open, robust deliberation.

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: The filibuster is about leverage, and that leverage is essential to maintaining equality and engendering deliberation among Senators.

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: Everything in the Senate is rooted in occupational equality of all Senators - filibuster protects this.

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: The Senate is broken, but the filibuster has almost nothing to do with it.

name: Mike Lee
tweet_text: Currently defending the need to preserve the Senate filibuster with @bdomenech https://t.co/K4sChFQ3xW
